awd_titl_txt: Stochastic Network Dynamics: Approximation, Analysis and Control
awd_abstract_narration:
Stochastic models of complex networks with dynamic interactions arise in a wide variety of applications in science and engineering. Specific instances include biochemical reaction networks, high-tech manufacturing, computer systems, telecommunications, transportation and business service systems. The analysis and control of such complex stochastic networks require solving challenging mathematical problems. This award supports research on solving such mathematical problems. Some of the work involves the development of general theory for broad classes of stochastic networks, while others focus on mathematical problems directly motivated by specific applications. Since the complexity of stochastic networks usually precludes exact analysis of detailed "microscopic" models, the focus is on formulating and analyzing more tractable approximations. New techniques and results will be developed in such a way that they can be used by applied researchers in areas of application. The results of this research will be disseminated through publication in peer reviewed journals, by posting on the University of California's open access website and by presentations at mathematics, science and engineering conferences. The PI will help train new mathematics researchers through collaboration with early career researchers.

The research addresses mathematical problems associated with the analysis and control of stochastic network dynamics. Topics to be addressed include rigorous justification of approximations, analyzing and controlling the behavior of the approximate models, and interpreting the results for the original microscopic models. Two levels of approximation are considered: first order approximations called fluid models, and second order approximations which frequently are diffusion models. An important subtheme is understanding the interplay between levels of approximation. Five topics are proposed for study: diffusion approximations for (bio)chemical reaction networks, analysis of processor sharing networks, congestion control and resource entrainment in data networks, networks with random order of service and reneging, and dynamic control of stochastic processing networks. Some stochastic process aspects of these topics include rates of convergence in the approximation of density dependent Markov chains by reflected diffusion processes, analysis of measure-valued processes used to track residual job sizes or ages of jobs in stochastic network models with resource sharing, singular diffusion control problems, foundational questions for reflected processes, and numerical approximation of reflected diffusion processes in non-smooth domains. This award will support the training of early career researchers and underrepresented minorities through direct support of a female graduate student, and through collaboration of the PI with one early career researcher and one female researcher who is at a non-PhD granting institution.

por.por_cntn:
Stochastic models of complex networks with dynamic interactions arise in a wide variety of applications in science and engineering. The need to analyse and control such complex stochastic networks leads to challenging mathematical problems. This grant supported research directed towards solving such mathematical problems, relating to a range of applications.

Continuous-time Markov chain models are frequently used to describe the stochastic dynamics of networks of reacting chemical species, especially in the growing field of systems biology. Due to their complexity, these models are often studied via simulation; however, this is often very computationally intensive. An alternative approach is to seek diffusion approximations to these Markov chains. In joint work with Anderson, Higham and Leite, PI Williams developed a new reflected diffusion approximation called a Constrained Langevin Approximation (CLA) for such Markov chain models. The CLA has multiple advantages over prior approximations, such as the linear noise approximation and Langevin approximation. In particular, it is well-defined for all time, it respects the constraint that chemical concentrations are never negative, and it captures non-linearities in the noisy dynamics. Mathematically, the CLA was proved to be the limit of a sequence of natural jump-diffusion approximations to the Markov chain; under mild assumptions, the CLA was proved to be well defined for all time; and compelling examples illustrated to practitioners the implications for speeding up simulations by using the CLA instead of the Markov chain.

In computer networks, round-robin or time-sharing protocols are a common feature. For mathematical analysis of these systems, one usually considers the (idealized) processor sharing service discipline, in which a server shares its effort equally amongst all jobs currently at its station. Measure-valued processes, that track the residual size of all jobs in the system, are a natural way to represent the dynamics. However, due to their infinite-dimensional nature, analysis is challenging. In collaboration with Mulvany and Puha, PI Williams, established the asymptotic behavior of a measure-valued fluid model for a heavily loaded, multiclass, processor sharing queue, by introducing a novel relative entropy technique. This generalizes an earlier single class result of Puha and Williams to the more complex multiclass setting and uses a different technique, which is more amenable to generalization to the network setting.

In joint work with Fu, PI Williams studied the asymptotic behavior of a fluid model for bandwidth sharing in telecommunication networks, such as the Internet. In a first paper, Fu and Williams proved the stability for the subcritical fluid model. This paper gave a definitive proof of this question, which had been open for about twenty years. In a second paper, Fu and Williams, characterized the more subtle asymptotic behavior of the critical fluid model. This involved developing a new Lyapunov function for this measure-valued model. This result is expected to be useful for studying diffusion approximations for the bandwidth sharing model, and the new type of Lyapunov function is likely to be useful to researchers interested in the dynamics of other stochastic networks.

Traffic flow on freeways can be controlled through metering at onramps. The easy availability of real-time traffic information can affect driver behavior and thereby dynamically adjust traffic loads at onramps. The interaction of system controls and information dependent load is an understudied problem. As a step in this direction, in a joint work with Helton, Kelly and Ziedins, PI Williams characterized both the dynamics and the equilibrium behavior of a fluid model for a linear traffic network with information feedback and onramp controls. The paper developed analytical methods that yielded interesting qualitative insights about the bottleneck dynamics. The paper is a first step towards developing an analytical approach for networks with more complex topologies and model features.

Simple symmetric random walks, stochastic integrals and measure preserving transformations are fundamental to the theory of stochastic processes, as well as to a wide range of applications. In joint work with Collevecchio, Hamza and Shi, PI Williams investigated the properties of the most general discrete-time setting that combines all three. This work characterized all possible ways of recycling increments of a simple symmetric random walk into a new simple symmetric random walk adapted to the same filtration, and studied the long term behavior of the pair of random walks. Furthermore, a simple necessary and sufficient condition for the ergodicity of the recycling transformation was provided, generalizing prior results and solving the discrete version of an open problem on the ergodicity of the general Lévy transformation.

This grant supported the training of early career researchers and those who are underrepresented in STEM. This included direct supervision of 3 PhD students, two of whom are female and one of whom is Latino. PI Williams also mentored two postdocs, one of whom is female; and collaborated with one female professor and her masters’ student, both of whom are from a non-PhD granting institution.
